stem: A client with Myasthenia Gravis (MG) presents in respiratory distress. Based on the documentation in the Tensilon (Edrophonium) Challenge Log, what is the nurse's next immediate action?

tabs.title: Respiratory Status
tabs.content:
Situation: Weakness of the diaphragm; RR 10 and shallow.
Condition: Severe ptosis (drooping eyes). Inability to swallow saliva (Drooling).

tabs.title: Tensilon Test Log
tabs.content:
TimeActionResult
1000Administer Edrophonium (Tensilon) 2mg IVNo change in strength
1002Administer Edrophonium (Tensilon) 8mg IVWeakness WORSENS. Client is now unable to lift head. Bradycardia (HR 42) noted.

tabs.title: Medication History
tabs.content:
Chronic Meds: Pyridostigmine (Mestinon) 60mg every 4 hours.
Recent: Patient accidentally took a double-dose of Pyridostigmine this morning.

options.text: Administer IV Atropine and prepare for intubation
Administer an additional dose of Pyridostigmine
Increase the IV fluid rate to flush the Tensilon
Ask the client to cough and deep breathe

rationale.correct: This is a **Cholinergic Crisis (a1)**, not a Myasthenic Crisis. In the Tensilon test, if symptoms **worsen** or do not improve, it means the patient has *too much* acetylcholine (usually from an overdose of meds like Pyridostigmine). The **Bradycardia** and worsening weakness are definitive. **Atropine (a1)** is the antidote for cholinergic toxicity and must be given immediately along with respiratory support (intubation).
clinicalPearls: Myasthenic Crisis = Under-medicated (Needs MORE Acetylcholine). Improves with Tensilon.
Cholinergic Crisis = Over-medicated (Needs LESS Acetylcholine). Worsens with Tensilon.
Always have Atropine at the bedside during a Tensilon test.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the test made them **worse**, giving more of the drug (Pyridostigmine works like Tensilon) will stop their breathing entirely. Stop the 'Sludge' symptoms with Atropine.

mnemonic.title: SLUDGE
mnemonic.expansion: S-Salivation. L-Lacrimation. U-Urination. D-Defecation. G-GI upset. E-Emesis. (Signs of Cholinergic Crisis).
